docs.lead_paragraph: Renee Chelian was worried about her business. With competitors charging lower prices, she needed something special to draw customers. So she created an almost a spa-like atmosphere at her offices, with low light in the rooms, aromatherapy, candles and relaxing music. Ms. Chelian runs three abortion clinics in the Detroit suburbs, where competition is so fierce that each clinic owner is looking for an edge.

headline.main: As Abortion Rate Decreases, Clinics Compete for Patients

docs.abstract: As number of abortions has declined over past few years, abortions have increasingly been concentrated in specialty clinics in cities and pockets of competition have developed; so while women in rural areas must sometimes drive hundreds of miles to nearest clinic, in cities and suburbs there are price wars and competition over amenities; doctors refuse to train colleagues, fearing they will only help a potential competitor in lucrative, often cash-only, business (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The crucible that forged the character and politics of Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin was a 1940's general store in the farming-and-railroad town of Elroy, people who know him say. It was at that store, owned by his exacting father, that he was first put to work, at age 5, sanding and polishing the chicken droppings off eggs for sale -- the job in exchange for a tricycle he had asked for.

headline.main: Innovators on Welfare and Schools and an Opponent of Regulation; Tommy George Thompson
headline.kicker: THE 43RD PRESIDENT: THE CHOICES -- MAN IN THE NEWS

docs.abstract: Profile of Gov Tommy G Thompson, who gave Wisconsin the nation's toughest welfare-to-work program and has been nominated to be secretary of health and human services in Bush administration; photo (Man in the News) (M)

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers and management at The Seattle Post-Intelligencer cheered the end of a 38-day strike today, but at The Seattle Times, the city's other, larger daily newspaper, an acrid dispute over the terms of possible layoffs held up a conclusion to the strike there. In a strange turn of events, the Newspaper Guild today abruptly halted a vote that was being taken by guild members at The Times on a new contract offer after the nation's top federal mediator said there had been a miscommunication between the two sides in the labor dispute.

headline.main: Strike Continues at One Seattle Newspaper

docs.abstract: Dispute over terms of possible layoffs holds up conclusion to strike at Seattle Times; workers and management at Seattle Post-Intelligencer cheer end of their strike; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President-elect George W. Bush continued to build his cabinet team yesterday, mixing interesting choices for the departments of Education and Health and Human Services with an unsettling pick for the Interior Department. Both Tommy Thompson, the Wisconsin governor, who will run H.H.S., and Rod Paige, the Houston public school superintendent, who will run Education, will bring experience and a reputation for flexibility to their jobs. Gale Norton, the former Colorado attorney general, chosen for Interior, brings considerable familiarity with environmental issues but also a reputation as a dedicated property rights advocate with deep reservations about the Clinton administration's aggressive efforts to enlarge federal protections for wilderness and wildlife. Mr. Thompson is the architect of one of the country's most innovative welfare reform policies. As such, he promises to bring creativity to the federal agency that oversees welfare, Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. When he became governor in 1987, about 100,000 Wisconsin families collected welfare benefits. As he prepares to leave, the number is down, by one measure, to about 20,000. Wisconsin's robust economy has been one big reason for this decline. Another has been Mr. Thompson's innovative policies. Like others in his party, he preaches individual responsibility and work. Wisconsin's program puts everyone in some type of job, including community service for those unable to find employment in the private sector.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Gov Tommy G Thompson of Wisconsin promises to bring creativity to Health and Human Services Department, although there is danger that his strong opposition to abortion may undermine women's reproductive freedoms; says Rod Paige, Houston public school superintendent, seems a wise choice as education secretary; says Gale Norton, interior secretary-designate, must overcome her reputation as dedicated property rights advocate and show commitment to enlarging federal protections for wilderness and wildlife (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After 38 days on strike, workers at The Seattle Post-Intelligencer announced tonight that they had voted to accept a contract offer and return to work. But strikers at The Seattle Times, locked in a battle with management over the terms of possible layoffs, were still discussing a separate proposal and were not expected to complete a vote until Friday at the earliest. At The Post-Intelligencer, the vote to return to work was 88 to 29. The paper's management and union, the Newspaper Guild, said they expected striking employees to return to work early next week.

headline.main: One of Seattle's Newspaper Strikes Is Settled

docs.abstract: Workers at Seattle Post-Intelligencer vote to accept contract offer and end 38-day strike; strikers at Seattle Times are still discussing separate proposal (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WebMD, the biggest Internet company linking insurers, doctors and patients, said it had ended a partnership with DuPont in which the chemical maker provided online information and shared WebMD's revenue. The collaboration began in March 1999 and was to expire in March 2004. Under the agreement, DuPont was to provide health care content for WebMD's consumer and physician Web sites and create programs for the drug industry. Earlier this month, DuPont said it would split off its drug unit. WebMD is scaling back its consumer health Web site and focusing on providing software and electronic processing of health insurance claims as it aims to become profitable.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki voiced an unusually harsh criticism of the Clinton administration today, saying it has delayed approving an important waiver that would allow New York to begin providing coverage to low-income residents without medical insurance. Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said that the state had been planning to begin enrollment in January for Family Health Plus, a program that state leaders created last year to provide coverage for roughly one million of the three million New Yorkers without health insurance.

headline.main: Pataki Says U.S. Is Delaying A Health Insurance Expansion

docs.abstract: New York Gov George Pataki criticizes Clinton administration for not granting Medicaid waiver so state could begin implementing program that would cover low-income residents who do not have health insurance (M)
